@michael_merrick @DamsonEd I disagree. Teaching is hard mental work and we all need to be trained to a high standard to develop those habits of thought. Teaching is graduate level intellectual work and I believe people from all backgrounds can achieve that standard via varying routes. Let‚Äôs help them.

@michael_merrick I would agree with you if the only route to that degree was A-levels & 3 year unpaid BA. That is a closed shop. But that is not the case. I have two TAs starting on school-based paid routes next year. Excellent young women who will be the first in their families to get a degree.

@DamsonEd @michael_merrick And I think it‚Äôs important to show belief in our colleagues who want to try for this - with the right support they can make it. Paid routes are essential to this and thank goodness they exist.

@michael_merrick @DamsonEd We need the starting line of a degree to be in place so that there are the same fair opportunities for everyone to move onto leadership and HT positions too. We can‚Äôt have second class teachers who are stuck at a particular level because if their qualifications.
@michael_merrick @DamsonEd I disagree if there are enough routes to that endpoint. Non-trad routes, which build incrementally, really open doors and build confidence.

@michael_merrick Agree degree doesn‚Äôt guarantee quality in itself but it‚Äôs one indicator that people have the intellectual capacity for this intellectually challenging role. Why not continue to use the degree as part of being highly trained?

@michael_merrick I know several talented people who have not completed A-Levels or a degree and who are excellent TAs with the makings of excellent teachers. Let‚Äôs support them to fulfill their very realisable dreams, but the degree standard should stay.

@michael_merrick I feel bad Michael because I often agree with you and scroll on & here I am responding because I disagree but I do disagree. Teaching needs to remain a learned as well as a practical profession. I am all for having varied , helpful routes into it (e.g. apprenticeship degrees) /1

@michael_merrick @GrahamFrost1 @bekblayton Well we are where we are. And where we are is slightly more than half of voters opted to Leave, slightly less than half to Remain. Ignoring those numbers is foolish. Deals for leaving should be (or better, should have been) negotiated in light of those numbers. That‚Äôs democratic.

@michael_merrick @GrahamFrost1 @bekblayton Insistence on Democracy-as-a-Binary created the referendum question and then prevented the government (produced via our binary-favouring electoral system) involving parliament and cross-party involvement in a workable Brexit deal. Can‚Äôt British democracy do nuance?

@michael_merrick @GrahamFrost1 @bekblayton Democracy isn‚Äôt a zero-sum game is it? Win/lose, in/out, my way/your way. Structures can be put in place to ensure reasonable representation and a fair hearing for minorities (see Northern Ireland Catholics and GFA). Grown up leaders should be able to sit down and negotiate this.
